Worms Armageddon was the stand-alone expansion to arguably the best artillery strategy ever made... Worms 2. Though it lacks the insanely tweakable ammo and game settings of the original and doesn't have boobytrapped crates, WA is the best iteration in the series. Especially given that it's playable on modern Windows systems since the 3.16 patch.

Forget Reloaded and other new Worms games: this game delivers everything you'ld want in almost perfect style. Thing is: you could get really good at it. It allows a great deal of skill development and at the same time it's a very capable strategy in its own right. Figure out your own style of play: very creative or very effective. Mass damage or darksiding!

ALSO a must on any decent LAN so make sure everyone of your friends picks it up at a sale (or have a working install on your pc as the game is portable ;)

[EDIT]
I've read some negatives and wanted to give some heads-up to people that are unfamiliar with Worms games or with the old ones.

The full price of 15 euro's (or bucks or whatever) is quite a lot if you do not know what to expect. You'll probably better wait for a sale. Also, it's pretty smart to try and check if the game works on your system like it should beforehand. We have LAN's at least twice a year and some pc's have problems with the title, while others have no problem at all. I'm running Win10, my Win7 had no problems as well. I've seen people running 7,8 and 10 with and without problems, but mostly Win8 seems to be the biggest issue (which is to be expected of course :P). But as I said, I've never experienced problems on my systems after patch 3.16.

Furthermore there's quite a lot of contempt over the control scheme and that it isn't rebindable. I understand the issue, but that is indeed how old games often were made. And the game also provides few explanation about the mechanics involved. It's probably best to play with a friend that knows some of the basics, or someone that does want to give some education about it.

I'll consider making a small tut guide and vid if people'd like it and link it here and in the community hub.

reviewText:
The best Worms game to ever come out - seriously. If you are looking which Worm game to buy first, make it this one. Do not be fooled by my hours on steam, I've spent countless when I first bought the game back in 1999.

Worms Armageddon has single player elements and multi player elements to it. Traditionally, Worm games are turn based, and there can be two to four teams present on the battlefield. Each turn, a different worm has a chance to unleash mayhem. The playing terrain can be shot away with and you might find one of your worms just sitting above water, short of drowning. What makes this game dynamic is the multitude of weapons given at your disposal. Super sheep's that can fly through the air, controlled by the player. Holy hand grenades that take away a good chunk of the map. Banana bombs that bounce around everywhere and release more banana bombs. On the map as well, there are randomly placed proximity mines and fire barrels that explode and spread fire when provoked.

One player training missions are available and make for a good challenge and breakaway from single player mode. Teams can be customized from grave choice to voice type, even a flag can be thrown into the mix to represent your team. Custom names can also be given to team worm players.

This game is a good local game to play with friends, and probably is the only turn based game I'd be willing to play at any time. Absolutely, I would say this game is what made the series.

I would like to see maybe in a future Worms' series a real-time worm game rather than turn based. How would that work? Well if I got paid for further suggestions in my reviews I'd share how :).

reviewText:
I bought this game on Dreamcast around 1999, not knowing what to expect, which I think allowed me to find hidden gems like Worms Armageddon. I had never played a Worms game before and was on the hunt for any great game in the limited library available on the Dreamcast. Going back to that day, it has been nearly 15 years. It's amazing to think this game still holds up so well. Since then I have played several Worms games, almost all have fallen short of the complexity, difficulty, and variety that WA offered me as a child.

This is a great game to play in a room with several people, which may be hard to do on the PC version. Most of those days are lost, but when you try to carefully plan out an assassination, walking and jumping through mines, from perfectly landing Ninja Rope insanity, only to end up undershooting a Holy Grenade and blowing your elite worm 300 yards into the water -- the room of viewers will burst into laughter and you won’t care that you probably lost the game. Moments like these are what make the Worms games so great. The newer Worms games offer online and clan wars, but lets be honest... That is a dull experience in comparison. Online can be fun, don't get me wrong, but it is totally competitive and not intended for newer players.

I must also mention in a bit of detail, the Ninja Rope. It has since dramatically changed in all Worms, but in my opinion, not for the better. The classic Ninja Rope took a ludicrous amount of skill and refinement. Not everyone could master it, but those that did, were true bad asses. It is one of the funnest tools in any Worms game, and makes this classic stand out amongst all the sequels. Let me just say, it is a little overpowered. Just like how everyone remembers Quake for Rocket Jumping
date:
the older Worms games are remembered for Ninja Ropes.

The single player in this game was pretty tough, and if you have troubles, check out my video tutorials on completing it (on Steam or YouTube). It is pretty fun though, and teaches you several tricks of the trade. I would say to try and complete the training and a few campaign missions before ever playing online. This should give you the basic understanding of how to utilize your weapons/tools. Then see what people do online to become a pro. It takes some time and patience, but is worth it in the end when you start blowing egos into the water.

In short, if you're looking for a massive array of weapons, level designs, laughter, and difficulty -- look no further. This game is amazing 15 years later, and will be in another 15. Give it a try if you've found the newer Worms games a bit too easy or you've never played Worms at all. There’s no other games like them and there’s a reason Team17 (the creator) has prospered all these years as one of the oldest independent game companies around.

reviewText:
Worms has been around for years and still has new releases, yet this game remains on top.  There are two primary gameplay modes: Campaign and Deathmatch.

The campaign is comprised of different levels that teach you the gameplay mechanics and give you different goals to reach with a given set of weapons.  It starts out explaining how aiming, power, and wind effect different weapon such as grenades and the bazooka.  You quickly learn how different weapons react to different environments.  The game then puts you in situations where you have to get from point A to point B while only using specific utilities.  There are many levels that will only be completed through trial and error--and that is one of the best parts of the game--it doesn't hold your hand.  You learn how everything works through experimentation.  You learn for example, that a girder can be used for protection as well as to traverse the maps.

Death Match is a simple 1 on 1 where each player takes turns controlling an individual worm trying to eliminate the other team.  It starts out simple, giving you the obvious advantage in team size and poor ai aiming, while slowing ramping up the difficulty with each match.  By the end, you have a smaller team size and the ai has impeccable aim.  The last match will likely take many tries.  But, when you do win, you will feel like you truly earned it.

All Worms games follow the same mold, but what makes this one truly stand out is the customization.  You choose the name of every worm on your team as well as their gravestone and voice from a huge list of options.  When you want to face off with a friend or the ai, the game gives an astounding amount of options that are sadly lacking from more recent titles.  You can choose which weapons and utilities you want available (there is a lot to choose from!), how much ammo they have, when they can be used, etc.  You can choose how often health/weapons/utilities drop.  You have control over worm life and sudden death options.  You can essentially change anything you would possibly want.  Don't like the random stages the game gives you?  You can create your own stages as well!

One of the things that makes Worms Armageddon so great is that you can play multiplayer locally as well as online.  Sure, you can see all of your opponent's crate pickups during local play, but nothing beats being able to see their face when you land that amazing grenade toss to win the game.

Although newer titles may look nicer in the graphics department, this game still reigns supreme in terms of content and customizability.  This game was amazing in 1999, and it still holds up today in 2015.

The definitive Worms game that still, 15 years later beats all the competition. To this day no other Worms game has been able to reach this level of strategic versatility and creativity. If you want, you can play silly and just relax and have a great time with friends. You can also make it an honorable, chess-like duel of masterful maneuvers and strategies.

Compared to Reloaded and onwards, this game features more sensible physics that can be utilized to carry out pixel-precise maneuvers and strategic plans. Also, the Ninja Rope is as deadly as it's supposed to be, not the gimped and clumsy version featured in later installments.

Compared to Worms World Party, this game is still being updated and has been supporting high screen resolutions and modern operating systems for ages. Also some gameplay-related peculiarities have been fixed (like the difference between fall damage distance and parachute deployment distance), game settings are far more fine-tunable in the game UI, it's minimizable everywhere, maps can be of near arbitrary size, .png format maps are supported in online games, automatic game recordings etc... so yeah, there's a lot to improve in WWP RM.
The only thing missing from W:A are some Wormpot modes and I reckon the mission variety is not quite as wide.

Seriously, this is the best game ever made. I am not lying!
Ive played it for about hundret hours in its steam version.
Some years ago Ive played for even more hours with the retail version. (I have plenty of them, always managed to lose the disc at some point heh) And when I was a kid Ive played Worms World Party when it was released for even even more. With my schoolmates Ive played the demo version on the same map over and over again for I-cant-even-remember-how-many-times. I bet Im scratching on the thousand hours now.
I dont think I could handle any real professional player online. There were some years of inactivity in between my sessions.
But being the best isnt really the point of the game. The point is to play with others and having a great time.
Its turn based, so its ideal for chilled evenings. When your turn is over you can chat with your enemys in the chat. The most enjoyable moments are these when something funny happens, when a whole dozen of worms are flying through the air or when a tricky shot succeed. Or failed and killed your own team instead the enemy.
Really, there are so many cool moments in this game you dont have in any other kind of games.
If you dont know anyone who plays with you, you can join the online servers. Depending of the daytimes you will find others to play with. If you fear this game will ever stop being popular online: Dont worry. The userbase was never really shrinking since its release. Of course playing with relatives is still way cooler than doing so with strangers.
And a few of the developer are still working on this game. They do fixes, keep it running on up-to-date computers and adding features. Still the game itself stays oldschool. I bet you wont find any game which are still getting that much attention from their devs.
If you get the concept of the game and like online matches with up to 5 other people from all over the world, this is your game. I think the single player of Worms World Party is better, but nothing tops the multiplayer of this timeless classic!

reviewText:
(Hours logged in-game only apply to the Steam version of W:A I purchased. The actual amount of time I've spent playing this game is incalculable.)

Best game ever made, hands down.

Better than all of the newer Worms titles. (Although we shall see if W.M.D. ends up being any good.) Unbeatable replay value and deeply strategic gaming. This game literally never gets old.

I've been playing it online since 1999 and I'll be playing it until I die, probably.

Looks are deceiving - what appears to be a simplistic, cartoony game for kids is actually the best online multi-player turn-based strategy game there is. The learning curve is practically endless. No matter how much you've played, you can always improve.

This is also a fantastic choice for less hardcore Worms players if you merely want to have some 6-player action with your friends and laugh your heads off.

I really don't understand why this game isn't more popular. To this day I have yet to find any game with as much replay value due to how customizable it is, and community-created schemes and maps are abundant.

One word of warning to newbies: People have been playing this game for a LONG time. If you find yourself losing (and you will), don't be put off by it. Every match is a learning experience and this game takes time to master. Nobody becomes good at this overnight. The community in general is friendly and willing to answer questions.

This game is digital crack cocaine. Yes, the graphics are dated, but the gameplay is outstanding.

The classic. While I still love Worms 2 most of all, mainly due to the stellar soundtrack which they never came close to matching in the dozen sequels, this is definitely Worms 2.5. This is the old reliable workhorse of the series. There's still people online, and they've done a good job making this stay compatible for modern systems and supported well on Steam. What issues they cant fix on Windows 8 and such, they warn you about and suggest workarounds. Nice effort. Not many games from the late 90's are so usable on Steam with no tweaking.

I haven't played much Worms Revolutions and none of Clan Wars, but this still seems to be the Worms title with the most accurate gameplay. Everything is pixel perfect, and the physics can be counted upon to not screw you up unfairly. There's still a lot of charm here, and for people with very weak hardware, this is your game. This series has been milked pretty bad, and you aren't missing much from newer entries besides graphics and shuffling up the equipment. While some can argue the equipment here is unbalanced, that's why you can make your own incredibly detailed rulesets when playing. Create your own balance over time.

Anyway, good memories here, but no nostalgia goggles are worn.

I've spent hundreds and hundreds of hours on this game way, way back when it was first released. This game, Age of Empires II, and Starcraft I were the only games I played for months. Bazooka in particular has always felt just write on the 2D landscape in this game. But things like traversing the landscape, setting up traps, and strategizing combos worked well within this gameplay style.

Character customization is as charming as ever. The worms voices and sounds are still fantatically presented. The graphics are also better than what I remember from the 15 year old game.

Overall, this is one game I'll always cherish and looking forward to more zany battles with these dastardly invertebrates.

Is Worms Armageddon (1999) still good for today's standards?     HELL YEAH!
One of the best (if not the best) Worms classic games! There's little to add to it, as it's considered a masterpiece!
-Highly customisable solo AND multiplayer matches (With maps you can create using a built-in tool or advanced free programs in the community)
-Huge arsenal of weaponry (even compared with modern Worms games)
-Online Multiplayer (Yes! There're people still playing this 1999's game online. It's that good and classic!)
-Local Multiplayer with up to 6 teams and 48 worms (Thanks to the 2010 upgrade)
-33 solo missions that will gradually test your skills
-A Training session that can help you a lot
-A Deathmatch mode to entertain good players and make the hardened ones try to finish it
-Extras and Rewards that are given to you as you complete trainnings and missions (and can be easily unlocked with mods, if you wish)
-Many, many, many Addons and Mods from the community
-Many (new) graphic options to suite your pc configuration (but it doesn't replace the classic art style)

The game received a big upgrade in 2010, is updated from time to time, and can run in all machines (Windows, Linux and Macs). If a problem occur (which in unusual) you just need a quick look on google to find a solution.

I've spent more than 50 hours playing it solo and with friends. With you think my opinion is spoiled by nostalgia, know that I've only got my own copy in mid 2013.
If you are still not sure, buy it on sale, don't try any stratagie game, or consult a doctor

I'm thrilled with this game, have enjoyed it for many hours, and encourage you to give it a try.  But let's start with three annoyances I've noted:

1. LAN matches can't include computer opponents, which reduces versatility -- only PvP vs. your friends, no co-op vs. AI (my nephews prefer PvP in all games, but I prefer co-op -- and the other day when my nephew actually wanted a co-op match, I realized we couldn't do it).  I assume you can create allied teams of players but that means we'd need at least two more computers.
2. Teams are stored per-computer instead of per-Windows login -- I have to put up with my nephew's teams as part of my list (which irritates the OCD part of my brain), and at any time he could accidentally screw up or delete my teams.
3. Once a team is set to Human or AI, you can't change that.  If I want to sometimes play characters from Night Vale and sometimes fight them, I have to make two separate teams for that alone.

Other than that, I'm thrilled with this game.  Bought two copies for my nephews so they'd have something they could play against each other that wasn't zombie-themed or Minecraft, and I think I've had more fun with it than they have (though both find it quite fun).

Each team is composed of 8 worms with a personalized flag, gravestone, anthem (to play when you win), and accent.  The accents range from real-world languages to a variety of English-language accents to a variety of comedic accents (including the Three Stooges), a cyberspeech voice bank, and a drill sergeant (which I cheerfully used for my Buzz Lightyear team... it was kinda funny to hear Booster and XR shouting orders in drill sergeant form).

You can set up a variety of teams and play up to eight (I think) in one match.  You get to choose how many worms from each team get in the game, which teams are allied, and which teams have a positive or negative handicap (+/- 25% health). All with hilarious accents.  I haven't tried it yet but I'm pretty sure you could set up an all-AI game if you wanted to enjoy watching (or just listening to and occasionally glancing at) a match while doing something else.

So yeah, good game, well recommended. This game brings back a lot of childhood memories. Being re-united with what is arguably the best Worms game in the series is a fantastic feeling for a nostalgia junkie like me. But aside from nostalgia, the game itself has never failed to impress me.

The turn based gameplay means that every battle is unpredictable. Even if you're a veteran to the series, it's impossible to determine what might happen next. Why is Armageddon the best in the series? It gets it right off the bat. The interface is fluent, the visual style is the most memorable. The sounds are on point and the overall gameplay is smooth and straight forward. Plus, I've always believed that the selection of weapons in Armageddon has been better than the rest.

This game brings back a lot of childhood memories. Being re-united with what is arguably the best Worms game in the series is a fantastic feeling for a nostalgia junkie like me. But aside from nostalgia, the game itself has never failed to impress me.

The turn based gameplay means that every battle is unpredictable. Even if you're a veteran to the series, it's impossible to determine what might happen next. The sense of unknown with each battle keeps me coming back. The AI isn't the best in the world, but that's arguably a good thing, because it means they are prone to mistakes. And when they do make mistakes, the outcome is often hilarious. It compliments the witty charm of the game.

I love games that you can make your own and Worms Armagdedon is no exception. There are tons of ways to customize your team. The best part is undoubtably the wide range of voices you can apply. My personal favourites for general banter are the 'Danish Pyrus' and the 'Soul Man' voices, but there are countless others which you a bound to find at least mildly amusing.

Why is Armageddon the best in the series? It gets it right off the bat. The interface is fluent, the visual style is the most memorable. The sounds are on point and the overall gameplay is smooth and straight forward. Plus, I've always believed that the selection of weapons in Armageddon has been better than the rest.

If you're thinking of getting into the Worms franchise, I highly recommend getting this one first. As far as I'm concerned, its the most comprehensive of all Worms games. It's funny, its well paced and its very addictive. Plus, people like me who have potatoes for operating systems need not worry about hardware upgrades or any of that nonsense. Just install it and play to your hearts content.

Above all, this game has not aged in the slightest since its 1999 release, and that's extremely rare. This game is nothing short of a masterpiece. It gets a 10/10 from me. It is one of THE very best games I have ever played.

Worms: Reloaded, Revolution, Clan Wars- they're not terrible by a far stretch, but they all try to do one thing- recapture this exact game. The 3D rendered 2D gameplay offered by the newer iterations is very pretty, and water weapons, physics objects, worm classes, and so much more do make for great games, however they all still fail to capture exactly this game. It's hard to articulate exactly how perfect and balanced this is. Maybe it's the range of weapons that includes your typical bazookas and grenades alongside magic bullets and sheep strikes. Maybe it's the way it feels so much more responsive over all other iterations allowing for perfectly timed ninja rope swings. Hell maybe it's just nostalgia. One thing I can say though is that even after 15+ years, this game is THE Worms game that we all love and play. It's THE gold standard of Worms games that has yet to be matched. This game has a brilliant art style, ample options for customisation and map creation, is nicely patched to run on modern systems with a myriad of lovely little tweaks to keep it going, and is still one of the best local co-op games I have ever played. I can think of plenty of worse things to spend a tenner on!

Imagine a turn based game like smash, where everyone got 4 - 6 Nintendo guys, and then you blow each other up with bombs and stuff... (I wish)

While in smash, you just mash buttons and everything is over in no time, without anyone knowing who even killed whom, in Worms, everyone gets to watch every piece of the action. If someone did a realy sneaky move, to do something to you or your other opponent, then you will know it, you will see it, and you will get mad or laugh your ♥♥♥ off about it.
After the fight, you take a minute to start a new game, and in that minute, your friends and you can actually talk about what happened... people plan revenge... people plot things... Unlike in Smash like games, where after the fight, nobody know who killed whom, and you just start the next game, with again, everyone just mashing buttons, like last rounds...

If you are able to play this game locally, or with a voice setup with friends, it's one of the best game that you can quickly bring up and play for a few minutes or hours. Without the social aspect of... you know... trust and betrayal etc... there won't be much fun in this game for you.
